Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phase-field models, algorithms and simulations for multiphase complex fluids
Award.AbstractNarration:
Mixtures of two or more immiscible viscous and/or complex fluid components are widely used in many science and engineering applications, in particular, in designing advanced materials involving polymers, composites, gels, liquid crystals, etc. It is expected that the proposed models and numerical methods/simulations will contribute to a better understanding of the complex physical and mathematical issues related to multiphase complex fluids, and provide valuable information for the design of advanced materials and on the rheological and hydrodynamic properties of complex fluids. The proposed research will also provide valuable opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to engage in interdisciplinary research with strong ties to biological and engineering material systems, to learn critical skills of computational and applied mathematics, and to develop state-of-the-art numerical tools for science and engineering applications.

Flows of multiphase complex fluid mixtures usually involve the coupling of microstructures, interfacial morphology and macroscopic hydrodynamics. The complexity of these nonlinear couplings presents many mathematical challenges for modeling and algorithm development, numerical analysis and implementation. The proposed research aims at overcoming these challenges to design efficient and accurate numerical algorithms for nonlinear multiphase complex fluid systems that couple the microstructure, moving material interfaces and hydrodynamics. Very few efforts have been made to address these numerical challenges. This project will result in numerical schemes which satisfy discrete energy dissipation laws, and which allow large time steps and controllable error and capture the interfacial dynamics accurately. In addition, the developed predictive tools and numerical simulations will extend the applicability of mathematical analysis and numerical codes to physical problems of current interest, and contribute to a better understanding of pressing science and engineering applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the proposed research lies in the challenge to design efficient and accurate numerical schemes for the nonlinear multiphase complex fluid systems. By the end of the grant period, we have developed a series of thermodynamically-consistent complex fluid models, for instances, the complex fluid model by coupling the energetic phase field approach with orientational order parameter of liquid crystal; the two-phase incompressible Newtonian flow model with variable densities; the hydrodynamics coupled nematic liquid crystal model; the hydrodynamics coupled smectic-A liquid crystal model; the hydrodynamics coupled phase field model with moving contact lines and variable densities, etc. Formally, these models are highly nonlinear and coupled systems thus involve huge barriers to establish easy-to-implement numerical schemes with energy stabilities.  We address these numerical challenges due to these nonlinear couplings by developing a series of easily implemented numerical schemes, in particular, the fully-decoupled first-order time discrete scheme, the second-order partially decoupled linear scheme, etc. All these schemes can preserve the energy dissipation law at the discrete level thus can allow the large time stepping as well as the controllable accuracy. At each time step, these schemes only require solving only a sequence of elliptic equations. Thus these schemes are easy-to-implement and thus can avoid costly nonlinear iterations in practice.  Based on the models and developed algorithms, we have performed a series of numerical simulations for some specific physically motivated applications, for instances, the drop dynamics where we compare the dynamics of the viscous drop and liquid crystal driven by the gravity; the morphology of liquid defect dynamics; the multiple steady phases of homopolymer blends, etc.

 

All these proposed models and numerical simulations provide efficient tools for understanding the complex physics and mathematical issues related to the multiphase complex fluids. The results of the research have been disseminated via traditional approaches including professional conferences, posters, lectures, publications, etc. This grant provided partial financial support for two graduate students, and one had already graduated with the Ph. D degree.  The PI has made strong efforts to collaborate with researchers from various science and engineering fields, institutions, and universities. The research provides chances to graduate students to engage in interdisciplinary research with strong ties to other science and engineering fields and to learn critical skills of computational and applied mathematics.
